import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


house_lb = pd.read_csv('../input/hp-publicleaderboard/house-prices-advanced-regression-techniques-publicleaderboard.csv')
house_lb.info()
source.94281266:
plt.figure(figsize=(16,6))
plt.xlabel("Score")
plt.xticks(np.arange(0, 1, step=0.025))
plt.ylabel("Frequency")
plt.hist(house_lb['Score'], range=(house_lb['Score'].min(),0.5) ,bins=100)
plt.show()
source.eea90394:
quantiles=[]
for q in np.arange(0, 21, step=1):
    quantiles.append(np.percentile(house_lb['Score'],q))
    
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
df=pd.DataFrame({'Score':quantiles})
df.T
source.f3c79795:
quantiles=[]
house_lb_=house_lb.loc[(house_lb['Score']!=0.00044)]
for q in np.arange(0, 21, step=1):
    quantiles.append(np.percentile(house_lb_['Score'],q))
    
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)
df=pd.DataFrame({'Score':quantiles})
df.T

source.8d92670b:
### So what is a good score?
I think if you make it to 0.1200 you are really good (maybe already very good), below 0.1170 is pretty sure very good. What do you think? Where do the peaks come from, just coincidence? If you know more about it or have suggestions for improvement, write it to me in the comments.

PS: I have not looked at any notebook for this competition, maybe there is already a notebook similar to mine...
source.9cbb778f: ### First we look at a histogram of the scores to get a first impression of the distribution
source.36d0ec38: * In fact nothing new. We have already seen that it becomes very tight at 0.120 - 0.125. More than 10% of the participants are in this range. If we want to be in the top 10%, we need a score less than 0.12017, for the top 5% less than 0.11877. Maybe we should also drop the 0.00044 to get a more realistic ranking.
source.f71597a1: My first educational competition was the Titanic competition. In this competition I missed to check the leaderboard for any abnormalities before I started to create models. The problem with the Titanic competition is that there are so many cheated scores, so I had no clue which score was actually good. After some research I found [this notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/carlmcbrideellis/titanic-leaderboard-a-score-0-8-is-great), which gave me information about which score is good/to achieve and which inspired me to this notebook. This time I try to do it better and check the leaderboard for anomalies before I start...
source.aab6fca6: ### Now let's take a look at the quantiles
source.c3ac9079: * Again nothing new. I think there are three milestones that will give us a boost to the ranking when exceeded: 0.122, 0.120, 0.117
source.b5ad08a5: ### Now let's take a look at the most common scores
source.b6854e77:
* 55 participants with score 0.0044... Now we can almost be sure that this score is cheated somehow.
* 36 participants with score 0.11720. Coincidence?
* 74 participants with score 0.12010 - 0.12013. That is quite tight.
* 138 participants with score 0.40613, would bet that this is the sample_submission.
source.eb0b3c2f: ### Finally we take a look at the histogram of the top 20% scores
source.405ad6bf:
* Ok, we have a peak near zero, probably cheated again?
* A big peak at 0.125, any score lower is probably already very good. We'll look at this more closely later with quantiles.
* One peak at about 0.400, possibly the sample_submission?
